item.description:
@zyle1992 wrote:

Skyro:

To bad this is copied from TheNewBoston Tutorial.

There are too many similarities here for it to be a coincidence. I’m going to go ahead and say that you followed a tutorial, and I don’t see credit anywhere, and you’ve stated that you created it yourself, which ultimately becomes plagiarism. Plagiarism is not tolerated on these forums, especially in this section.

hahahah, you all flame, your all stupid, the purpose is to help people, this isnt my standard fools, I made a GUI browser which isnt newb standard, proves I know something about Java, anyway if I wanted to I could get my private tutor to teach me C/C++, I dont care, if people want to use it let them, check the GUI browser if you know a bit more about Java, this is for people who want to use a simple calculator, I clearly posted basic calculator, never did I mention that this was for Java Pros, it`s a quick, simple java calculator, you all have something against me.

This isn’t a calculator, this adds two numbers together. You copied the calculator from a tutorial, just as you did this.

Oh and,

your all stupid

item.title: A Basic Calculator Built Using Java
item.dc:creator: @Skyro Arbe
item.description:
@Skyro wrote:

[code=java]import java.util.Scanner;

public class Calculator {

/**
 * 
 * Static Doubles
 * 
 */

public static double FirstNumber;
public static double SecondNumber;
public static double Answer;

/**
 * 
 * Main Method
 * 
 */

public static void main(String args[]) {
	Scanner Calc = new Scanner(System.in);
	System.out.println("Enter the First Number: ");
	FirstNumber = Calc.nextDouble();
	System.out.println("Enter the Second Number: ");
	SecondNumber = Calc.nextDouble();
	Answer = FirstNumber + SecondNumber;
	System.out.println("The Answer is: " + Answer + ".");
}

}
[/code]
I copied that form TheNewBoston, just renaming a few variables and the way things are said and it’s the EXACT same so don’t tell me it isn’t Also, your variables and wording are the same.

Read full topic

item.title: A Basic Calculator Built Using Java
item.dc:creator: @Ruby_Forums_Coder Ruby
item.description:
@Ruby_Forums_Coder wrote:

If you were good with GUI’s, add a GUI to it.

Also, why don’t you make it accept addition, subtraction, multiplication and division? Just create a separate function for each and call it when it’s required. I have a PHP implementation of a calculator lying around somewhere, lemme go find it.

My PHP implementation, made this like 3 years ago, lol:

if(!$_POST['act']) 
{ 
echo ' 
<form method="post" action="'.$_SERVER['PHP_SELF'].'"> 
<input type="text" name="x" size="5">  
<select name="act"> 
<option value="add">[ + ]</option> 
<option value="sub">[ - ]</option> 
<option value="div">[ / ]</option> 
<option value="mul">[ * ]</option> 
<option value="pro">[ % ]</option> 
</select> 
<input type="text" name="y" size="5">  
<input type="submit" name="derp" value="calculate"> 
</form> 
'; 
} else { 
 if($_POST['act'] == 'add') 
{ 
$calc = ($_POST['x']+$_POST['y']); 
 $op = '+'; 
} 
 if($_POST['act'] == 'sub') 
{ 
$calc = ($_POST['x']-$_POST['y']); 
 $op = '-'; 
} 
 if($_POST['act'] == 'div') 
{ 
 $calc = ($_POST['x']/$_POST['y']); 
 $op = '/'; 
} 
 if($_POST['act'] == 'mul') 
{ 
 $calc = ($_POST['x']*$_POST['y']); 
 $op = '*'; 
} 
 if($_POST['act'] == 'pro') 
{ 
 $calc = (($_POST['x']*$_POST['y'])/100); 
 $op = '% of'; 
} 
 echo $_POST['x'].' '.$op.' '.$_POST['y'].' = '.$calc; 
}

Read full topic

item.title: A Basic Calculator Built Using Java
item.dc:creator: @dclawed dclawed
item.description:
@dclawed wrote:

[quote=“tyb97, post:3, topic:458029”]Funny enough, I made this as one of my first Java programs as well
To go down your issues here though, you can’t have spaces in object names, and conventions, conventions, conventions.

[code=Java]
import java.util.Scanner;

public class JavaCalculator {

private static Scanner name = new Scanner(System.in);

public static void main(String args[]) {

	double firstnum, secondnum, answer;

	System.out.println("Enter the first number:");

	firstnum = name.nextDouble();

	System.out.println("Enter the second number:");
	
	secondnum = name.nextDouble();
	
	answer = firstnum + secondnum;
	
	System.out.println(answer);
}

}
[/code][/quote]

Ok lol, and yes it probably will be the same, were using the same coding language, its not going to be exactly the same as I havent copied it or anything, this is 100% my work.

Read full topic
